user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl(uint16 *PortNum, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr)
{
    in_port_t                     sa_port;
    const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *Accessor;

    Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;

    switch (Accessor->sa.sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in.sin_port;
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            sa_port = Accessor->sa_in6.sin6_port;
            break;
#endif
        default:
            return OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
            break;
    }

    *PortNum = ntohs(sa_port);

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_SocketAddrGetPort_Impl:
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef union
{
    char               data[OS_SOCKADDR_MAX_LEN];
    struct sockaddr    sa;
    struct sockaddr_in sa_in;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
    struct sockaddr_in6 sa_in6;
#endif
} OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t
...
#define OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS (-34)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment takes the address of the object pointed to by the parameter Addr and assigns it to a local pointer (Accessor = (const OS_SockAddr_Accessor_t *)&Addr->AddrData;). It does not modify the parameter pointer Addr itself nor PortNum. Therefore Rule 17.8 is not violated. (A violation would occur if the code assigned to or changed the parameter itself, e.g. Addr = NULL; or Addr = some_other_pointer;.)
